title: (x) Raised account numbers on credit cards - custom OCR face {Patricia}
content:
Coud someone please tell me what font is used for the raised account numbers on credit cards?

 [‹ (x) Mads Nørgaard, Danish fashion design - custom face by e-types {Ulli Neutzling}](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39774 "Go to previous forum topic") [(x) Inline gothic in Jimmy John's ad - H&FJ Cyclone {Paolo Mazzetti} ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.typophile.com/node/39961 "Go to next forum topic")
author: Koppa

comments.content: Some sort of OCR I’d think. Not likely a commercial font exactly, since special equipment is required.

I’ll second that. Here are some [OCR fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.fontshop.com/search/?q=ocr&sample_text=0123456789%20MONEY&sample_size=36).

<cite>Not likely a commercial font exactly</cite>  
I wouldn’t be surprised if such a font appeared in the [Lineto library](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/lineto.com/The+Fonts/) some day …

There are a “free” font called Halter by Apostrophic Lab out there that may do the trick. Otherwise if you just want the look and feel of the credit card characters I think you’ll like Ray Larabie’s [Kredit](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/larabie/kredit/)...
This is inquiry was a favor for a friend...on her behalf, thank you all.

David H. Shepard, the inventor of the optical character recognition device, dies at 84 ( [New York Times](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.nytimes.com/2007/12/11/us/11shepard.html) – via [Fontblog.de](http://web.archive.org/web/20080613021218/http:/www.fontblog.de/entwerfer-der-plastikkartenziffer-gestorben)).
